text: DIRECT EXAMINATION
Good morning, Doctor.
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Good morning.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: As I already introduced myself, I am Jillian Corbett and I represent Terea Thornton. Would you please introduce yourself to the jury this morning.
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: My name is Dr. Louis Olegario.  I'm one of the physicians from DNA Advanced Pain Treatment Center.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And we're here today to take your testimony on behalf of Ms. Thornton regarding your evaluation of her that was performed at my request and also your treatment of her following a September 1, 2016 motor vehicle accident. But before we do all of that, I need to ask you a few questions about your background and qualifications as an expert witness.  So what type of doctor are you?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So I'm -- I did finish my residency training in physical medicine and rehabilitation, and then I did a fellowship for interventional pain management.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are you licensed to practice medicine in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Would you explain for us a little bit what interventional pain management is.
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So for interventional pain management what we do with that is we treat a lot of chronic pain patients. That's including after back or neck surgeries or any motor vehicular accident, any trauma, cancer patients.  We do treatments such as injections, medications, physical therapy.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And could you explain for us a little bit what physical medicine is?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So physical medicine and rehabilitation, being -- that's why we call ourselves a physiatrist.  So we -- physiatrists we treat a lot of neurological problems, such as a stroke patients, trauma -- traumatic brain injury, spinal cord injury patients, even with musculoskeletal problem, any kind of chronic pain problems too.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long have you been a doctor?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: I have been licensed here in Pennsylvania since 2003.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And could you describe for the jury the process of how you became a doctor?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So becoming a doctor you have to have a bachelor's degree, a four-year bachelor's degree, and then a four years also in proper medical school, which I did finish my medical school in the Philippines, and I did one year of post graduate internship out there and then took my Philippines board before coming here.  Here in the states you have to pass USMLE I and II before you can start doing your residency training and then pass the USMLE III is when you can -- you are eligible to take your specialty board.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, you mentioned going to medical school in the Philippines.  Are you from the Philippines?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you also mentioned taking boards.  Are you board certified in Pennsylvania?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: How did you become board certified?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So board certification for physical medicine and rehabilitation you have to have four years of residency training, so one year in general surgery as an internship, visiting SUNY Downstate, Brooklyn, New York. Then I did my three years of residency training in physical medicine and rehabilitation in Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center.  It's also in Brooklyn, New York.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, are you also board certified in interventional pain management?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I am.  After taking that one year of interventional pain fellowship, then that's where you are eligible to take the pain management exams.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are you board certified in any other states?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: I have license in the State of Florida and some inactive license in New York and New Jersey.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, what does it mean when a license is inactive?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: What it means there is like, you know, since you're not practicing there actively, you can just put on hold all of those requirements that they need so you don't have to do that until like, you know, you try to practice in that state, then you can actively fulfill all of those requirements.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And have you ever been qualified to testify as an expert in Allegheny County?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, could you look at this exhibit that I have marked as A in front of you?  Could you please identify that document?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: (Olegario Exhibit A was marked for identification.)
Yes.  This is my recent curriculum vitae.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And would you tell the jury about any type of positions and professional associations you have.
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.  I am a member of Pittsburgh Pain Society as well as Washington Pain Society and a member of Pennsylvania Medical Society, American Academy of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation as well as American Board of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation.  And I do some teaching also with some students who comes.  These are nursing students from the University of Pittsburgh who comes to our office where we teach them what we do in the office.  We do teach them the anatomy, the injections that we do, the surgery that we do in our practice.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, you talked a little bit about being from DNA Pain Management.  So let's talk about your current practice.  What do you do on a daily basis?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: In my daily basis it really depends, because sometimes I'm in the office, sometimes I'm in the surgery center or hospitals.  So when I'm in the office, I do see patients, around 35 patients.  These are all including follow-ups, new patients, as well as injections.  And then if I am in the surgery center or in the hospitals, a lot of those procedures are patients needs sedations, because they are scared of needles, as well as surgical cases like spinal cord stimulator, Morphine pumps, kyphoplasty and all of the surgeries that we do under sedations.  So that's what we do in the hospital or surgery center.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, what types of procedures -- or what type of procedures do you perform?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So basically we do all of the joint injections. I do all of the epidurals, cervical, thoracic, lumbar.  I do sacroiliac injections, facet or a medial nerve branch block from cervical, thoracic, and lumbar.  I do kyphoplasty, vertebroplasty.  We do provocative discogram, spinal cord stimulator trial as well as the implants and Morphine pumps.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, do you treat patients who have suffered a trauma, a physical trauma?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And as part of your practice do you review medical diagnostic tests?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And does your practice include diagnosing patients and projecting their future treatment?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are you familiar with the costs associated with future treatment?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I am.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how are you familiar with those costs?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: This is just based on my clinical experience.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Thank you, Doctor.  At this time I'm going to allow opposing counsel to ask questions about your qualifications, and I would move to enter Exhibit A.
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: No objection. VOIR DIRE EXAMINATION
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Hi, Doctor.  Just a few questions.  Again my name is Nicholas Borsuk.  I represent the defendants in this action.  Thank you for being here today, sir. When did you begin practicing medicine in the United States?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Are you asking after my residency training?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After your residency training.
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: 2003.  And when did you begin that residency training in the United States?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: When?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: When, yes.
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: I did internship in general surgery in July of 1998 to June of 1999.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So prior to that, where were you practicing, sir?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: So I was working as a house staff physician in the Department of Neurosurgery at SUNY Downstate and Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn, New York.  That's in May of '97 to June of 1998.  Prior to that, I did some observership in, visiting Miami, Florida in Miami Children Hospital, and then I did work back in the Philippines also for about three years, from '90 -- January of '93 through December of 1996.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, I just wanted to confirm.  You have two current certifications; is that correct?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And that is a PM&R?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: That's correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: As it appears on your curriculum vitae?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And can you just again explain what is PM&R, what that abbreviation stands for?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: It's physical medicine and rehabilitation.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And the other certification you have is for pain management?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I have no further questions.
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Thank you.  At this time I would offer Dr. Olegario as an expert in interventional pain management and physical medicine and rehabilitation.
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: No objection.
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: ----- DIRECT EXAMINATION (CONTINUED)

Now, Doctor, as I said before, we are here today to take your testimony on behalf of Ms. Thornton who you have treated and also evaluated at the request of my office related to her treatment following her accident on September 1st of 2016. So during this testimony, I'm going to ask you for some opinions and potentially diagnosis, but I don't want you to give any of those opinions, unless you can do so to a reasonable degree of medical certainty.  Is that fair?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So my office asked you to prepare a narrative report so that you could testify in this matter on behalf of Ms. Thornton.  Could you please take a look at what I have marked as Exhibit B.  And do you recognize that document?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: (Dr. Olegario Exhibit B was marked for identification.)
Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that the report that you prepared regarding Ms. Thornton?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, it is.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So, Doctor, I'm going to ask you to refer to your report as needed during the course of your testimony here today.  Okay?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Okay.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you evaluate Ms. Thornton yourself?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And had you also treated Ms. Thornton for injuries associated with this accident before your evaluation at the request of my office?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you saw Ms. Thornton to treat her, did you perform a physical exam?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you also saw her to prepare this report, did you perform another physical exam?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: In a moment I'm going to ask you to work -- walk the jury through your physical exam.  But before I do that, I would like to know prior to your examination of Ms. Thornton, did you have an opportunity to review any treatment records regarding her care?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what were those?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So I did review her magnetic resonance imaging of her cervical and lumbar spine.  I did -- I do have some records also from Dr. Holding about the patient's electrodiagnostic study results and from her chiropractor, from Dr. Petrarca, and some of the notes that was given to me from Mercy Hospital.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, the records from Mercy Hospital, were those given to you by my office at a later date?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did any of those change the opinions that you gave in your report?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, you had mentioned some diagnostic tests that you reviewed.  And what were those tests?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So MRI of her cervical and lumbar spine as well as the electrodiagnostic studies of her upper and lower extremities.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, what did the MRIs show?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: The MRI of her cervical spine it shows normal results, and then the MRI of her cervical results are normal.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, what does an MRI image show?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Um --
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What is it -- I'm sorry.  That was a bad question.  What is it -- what is the test taken for or what is an MRI, rather?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So MRI stands as magnetic resonance imaging. What it does it uses powerful magnets and radio waves. With the help of the computer, it can generate all of this films.  It doesn't emit any radiation in comparisons to x-rays and CAT scans.  It's a very safe procedure, a very thorough test.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you had mentioned also an EMG test.  What is an EMG?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: EMG is really electrodiagnostic studies.  It involves two portions which is the first one is the nerve conduction studies and that one is a needle electromyography.  So nerve conduction study, so it will tell us if there is any nerve pathology, and then the needle EMG it will show if the nerve pathology is an acute or a chronic.  So it's how the muscle responds to any nerve stimulus.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And so what is the difference in what an EMG tests and what an MRI tests?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So MRI the way we see the MRI it easily represents the anatomy of the problem.  So it will show us if there is any anatomical problems of the spine or in the subcutaneous tissue or in the spinal cord.  In comparisons to electromyog --electrodiagnostic studies, it's more on the function of like where the nerve coming from the neck down to the arms, if there is any problems on the way from the neck down.  So it's more on the physiological side.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did the EMGs taken of Ms. Thornton reveal?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: She has two electrodiagnostic studies.  Her lumbar electrodiagnostic study shows no evidence of lumbar radiculopathy or peripheral nerve entrapment, and her cervical, her upper extremities, electrodiagnostic study shows cervical radiculopathy involving bilateral C5-C6 and right C6-C7 nerve roots.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, we can keep talking about cervical and lumbar.  Could you tell us what the cervical spine is or what part that is?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Cervical is mainly the neck area, so it is composed of a seven vertebra bone.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what about the lumbar?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Lumbar is in our lower portion of the spine.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you kind of discussed that radiculopathy was found in the cervical spine of Ms. Thornton.  What is radiculopathy.
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So radiculopathy are when there are some nerve pathology that causes some pain from the neck down to their hands, their arms, their fingers, shooting pain, aching pain, or like an electric type of pain.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, is it fully necessary for an MRI and an EMG to both show results or be abnormal for there to be radiculopathy in a patient?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: No, not necessarily.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how is it that they can be different?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So first and foremost it's like, you know, those diagnostic studies are just -- it's just going to help the providers.  It's really basically the history and physical is what's most important.  And some of these tests it could be negative, but it doesn't mean that the patient doesn't have the problem.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how does radiculopathy occur?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So radiculopathy once there is a nerve type of problem that's coming from the cervical spine and it manifest in the -- in their arms, forearms or in their fingers.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how can it be caused from trauma, if it can?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So what it does it involves when there are some nerve damage or any irritations from the nerve root that it can cause inflammation, and those inflammation is the one that is really causing all of this pain that it radiates down to their hands and fingers.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And in addition to these diagnostic studies and the other records that you told us you reviewed, did you, I believe you said you did, do a physical exam of Ms. Thornton?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what did that reveal?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So Ms. Thornton's cervical spine the range of motion is decreased in all directions, especially on cervical extension and flexion and also lateral rotation. She had some tenderness on both trapezius, the left shoulder area, and pain going down to her forearm and arm.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did your examination of her match the results of the objective testing?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, it did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: After examining Ms. Thornton, reviewing her records, studies and images referenced in your report, did you find any injuries?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what were those?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: That Ms. Thornton has a cervical radiculopathy as well as her facet injury as a result of the motor vehicular accident on September 1, 2016.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And when you first saw her for treatment, was she still suffering from pain from the accident?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, she was.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was that about a year after the accident that you first saw her?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Is that typical for pain management?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: It's really not unusual.  A lot of our patients since we treat chronic pain, a lot of them they refer to us six months to a year or even two years after like when their pain persist.  That's why we mainly treat chronic pain problems.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what does chronic mean?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Chronic means like, you know, when -- I mean, there is three stages; there is an acute, subacute, and a chronic.  So acute is within three months -- within a month, and then subacute is within three months of the problem, and then three months after that it becomes chronic, and that's when the problems persist, and then that's when we start seeing all of this patient.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And after reviewing the records and examining Ms. Thornton, I believe it was in September of 2017, what did you decide to do for her treatment-wise?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So after my evaluation with her, since her pain is mainly in the cervical spine down to her arms, so we discussed doing a cervical epidural steroid injections.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And was one of those eventually performed?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is a cervical epidural steroid injection?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So cervical epidural steroid injection usually what I usually tells my patients is it's basically exactly the same when women gives birth, so it's an epidural injection.  So the only difference is I use is an x-ray machine to guide my needle, and then I use steroids instead of the pain medication where these women -- the pregnant women gets.  So steroids is a very good anti-inflammatory medications.  It relieves the inflammations around the nerve root sheath, and once the inflammation subsides, then the pain coming from the neck down to their arm starts getting better.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, did you see Ms. Thornton again at a later date?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes, I did.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did she report to you whether or not her injection had helped?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: According to Ms. Thornton, she said it's a hundred percent relief from the injections.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long does relief from an injection typically last?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: It really depends from patient to patient, so it depends how bad the problem is also.  It could last from months to even a year.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, after reviewing all of the diagnostic records and your own examination and also the prior records from the Rehab Center and UPMC, do you have an opinion to a reasonable degree of medical certainty what injuries Ms. Thornton suffered as a result of the motor vehicle accident of September 1st of 2016?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is that opinion?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: That Ms. Thornton has a cervical radiculopathy involving bilateral C5-6 and right C6-C7 nerve roots as well as cervical facet injury.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how can that occur in a motor vehicle collision?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So usually when you get hit from behind, it could damage the -- some of the cervical facet joints.  It could cause some inflammation, and also it could irritate where the nerve root also comes out in the cervical foramen and it can irritate that nerve root there, because they are very sensitive to any kind of pressure.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, what is your prognosis for Ms. Thornton?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Ms. Thornton's prognosis is guarded.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: What does that mean?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: So guarded means like, you know, Ms. Thornton might need more injections down the road, as well as frequent follow-up just to make sure like, you know, it improves her quality of life.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did you make any recommendations about any future medication treatment for Ms. Thornton?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what were those?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: My recommendations for her is we can repeat the cervical epidural steroid injections.  Usually, as per my discussion with the patient, we usually do between three injections in a year.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And how long does someone typically need these injections?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Usually there is no really specific time limit but it can be undetermined.  Like, you know, it depends how bad the problem and if it persists.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, would Ms. Thornton's age have anything to do with her ability to recover or her injuries?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: It's going to be hard for her, because like, you know, once you have a chronic problem, it's going to be there.  There will be times that her pain is going to be worse no matter what she's going to do.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And Doctor, you have performed cervical epidural steroid injections, as we discussed.  Could you estimate the cost of that treatment?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: The injection usually cost between $850 to 1,100 per injection.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And are those cost projections based on your experience in a clinical outpatient and surgical setting?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Are your opinions about Ms. Thornton's future treatment held to a reasonable degree of medical probability?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you have reviewed multiple treatment records for Ms. Thornton.  Do you have an opinion as to the reasonableness and necessity of all of the treatment that she has had to date?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And what is that?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: That all of the treatment that Ms. Thornton received up to this times are reasonable.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And finally, Doctor, have you given all of your opinions today to a reasonable degree of medical certainty?
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: I would offer Dr. Olegario on cross. CROSS-EXAMINATION
speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: Good morning, Doctor.  I have a few questions I would just like to go over before we get into your reports.  You are a doctor for -- in layman's terms, you are a doctor for pain management; correct?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: We can agree that pain generally is a matter is subjective?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: It's subjective, and then it could -- we try to incorporate with our physical findings.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Understood.  But there is no, for lack of a better phrase, painometer like there is so that you check your heart rate or something like that; correct?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Doctor, in reviewing your report of November 13, 2018, did you personally write this report, sir?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Every aspect of it?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Uh-huh.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  In your report and during your testimony here, you make several statements regarding the plaintiff's position in the vehicle, wearing a seat belt and where the accident actually occurred as to the contact.  This information was provided to you by the plaintiff; correct?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: With the patients, yes.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And -- but you never saw the vehicle that was involved in the accident?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: The picture of the accident?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes.
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: No.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And you never went to the scene of the accident?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And at the time of this report you never saw the hospital records; correct?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Do you remember when exactly you first saw the hospital records?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: It was just sent to me last week.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  So when you physically examined the patient, Ms. Thornton, you still had not seen the hospital records; correct?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: At that time there is none.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  Doctor, I want to go a little bit into the medical records of Ms. Thornton and if you need to look through your file to follow along.  It appear that her first chiropractic visit was on October 4, 2016.  Is that correct?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  And her next visit wasn't until January 2017, three months later?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: From the chiropractor?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: From her first chiropractic.
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: I think she was seen every two days.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Every two days?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Yes.  She has October 4th and October 6th.  Is that what you are asking?
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Yes; that's what I'm asking.
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Yeah.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: So she was going every time?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Yes.  I think two to three times a week.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: To the chiropractor?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: That is correct.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Okay.  According to Ms. Thornton's records, medical records, she was prescribed some pain medicine -- medication; is that correct?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: She was given Ibuprofen which is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medication.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Anything else other than the Ibuprofen?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: As far as I know, I think she was given also a muscle relaxer, Flexeril.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: Did she tell you if she ever took that prescription?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: Those are the prescription that was given to her when she went to emergency -- emergent -- Mercy ER.
speaker: THE WITNESS

text: And did -- Doctor, I will re-ask my question. Did she ever inform you if she took that medication?
speaker: MR. BORSUK

text: She did take the Ibuprofen.
speaker: THE WITNESS

speaker: MS. CORBETT

text: With the medication itself.  You know, I mean, if you take a lot of steroids, it's not good for the bones.  It can cause a lot of other problems also, and also we have to ask if the patients are diabetic, because sometimes their sugar goes up.  So we try not to load with a lot of steroids and that's one of the reasons for that, and also their adrenal glands, it could make some problems with that also.
